Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Underactuacted Precision Robotic Grasping and Manipulation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The vision of robotic assistants for domestic, health care, and workplace applications will not come to fruition without the ability to manipulate typical objects in human environments. However, grasping is challenging in unstructured environments because object models typically required to control the robot are not known beforehand and must be acquired through sensors that are imprecise and incomplete. The majority of research in robotic grasping and manipulation has attempted to address this problem through elaborate multifingered hands combined with tactile sensing and sophisticated planning and control algorithms, often following an anthropomorphic approach. This proposal utilizes an alternative approach involving a focus on the mechanics of the hand itself to accomplish most of the needed ?control.? By appropriately incorporating features such as compliance and underactuation, the uncertainty inherent in unstructured grasping tasks can be more easily accommodated. The proposed work addresses the problem of precision grasping of small objects from the surrounding environment and then begins to address the broader problem of dexterity by examining two-fingered precision manipulation, while investigating the role of compliance, underactuation, and configuration on performance in the presence of uncertainty. This work will be disseminated through publications in scholarly journals and conferences and will contribute to the fundamental understanding of the mechanical interaction of robot hands with small objects and the surrounding environment. These results are expected to lead to the development of low-dimensional hands for precision robotic grasping and manipulation with applications including assistive robots and prosthetics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project utilized an alternative approach involving a focus on the mechanics of robotic hands to accomplish most of the needed “control.” By appropriately incorporating features such as compliance and underactuation, the uncertainty inherent in unstructured grasping tasks can be more easily accommodated. These features can reduce the need for complicated sensing and control by allowing for passive adaptation to the object properties and positioning errors, making the hand easier to operate, more robust, and less expensive. This work therefore focused on three aspects of the mechanics of robot hands for manipulation in unstructured, real world environments:

  • Passive compliance to keep contact forces low and allow passive deflection under unwanted contact.
  • Adaptive underactuation to reduce the number of actuators and simplify the sensing and control of the manipulator.
  • Robust construction for reliability and preventing damage when the inevitable unplanned contact occurs.

In terms of intellectual merit, findings from the effort include:

- a precision (2-fingered) planar hand with only two actuators can successfully grasp and manipulate (in 2 degrees of motion - one per actuator) an object held in a precision grasp. This is in contrast to previous results that have required that each finger have n actuators for n object degrees of controlled movement. We have shown that, through the use of underactuated mechanisms and appropriately placed mechanical compliance, the whole hand can have n actuators total for n object degrees of movement.

- a thorough classification scheme for in-hand manipulation that will prove useful for robotics, prosthetics, rehabilitation, biomechanics, and surgical applications. We have also, in the process, reviewed related classification schemes, and helped to standardize related definitions and terms.

- shown robust precision grasping of a wide range of small objects (down to <2mm thickness) from tabletop surfaces with purely open-loop control and insensitivity to positioning errors. This is extremely difficult for other hands to do, and very little prior success has been demonstrated.

- demonstrated precision in-hand manipulation with planar two-fingered hand (underactuated with two actuators), in which a range of objects are manipulated between the fingertips of the hand in a wide workspace.

 

- developed a simple and robust sensing modality to detect contact anywhere on a compliant structure. The method uses only a single accelerometer and a phase-locked-loop circuit to detect the changes in resonant frequency of the finger due to contact. This incredibly inexpensive method is promising in that contact does not need to occur on a 'sensorized surface', which is the norm in the field, but can be useful for the whole structure. Additionally, we found accuracy comparable to other tactile sensing technologies that are orders of magnitude more expensive, limited to small surfaces, and are fragile.

 

- robust hands can be fabricated with 3D printers and off-the-shelf parts, if designed and manufactured properly

 

- dexterous, within-hand manipulation can be modeled as a parallel platform, drawing from the deep literature in that research domain

 

- human hand function can be approximated by a relatively small number of grip types and within-hand manipulative movements

 

Broader impact of the work includes the open-source dissemination of many of the robot hands designed during the work through the Yale OpenHand Project.
